text: Overexpression of <extra_id_0> protein kinase C-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulates leukemic cell differentiation .

text: A function for <extra_id_0> protein kinase C-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> PKC-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , a member of the phorbol ester nonresponsive atypical protein kinase C subfamily , in modulating differentiation was examined in the leukemic U937 cell .

Transfected U937 cells stably overexpressing <extra_id_0> PKC-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> displayed a longer doubling time , lower saturation density at confluency , and an increase in adherence to plastic as compared to control cells .

text: <extra_id_0> PKC-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cells expressed a more differentiated phenotype as assessed by changes in morphology , surface antigen expression , and lysosomal enzyme activities and were distinct from parental U937 cells stimulated to differentiate by exposure to phorbol esters .

In contrast to parental U937 cells , <extra_id_0> PKC-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cells constitutively expressed mRNA transcripts for <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and a low mobility AP-1 binding activity .

Thus , <extra_id_0> PKC-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression stimulates a type of phenotypic differentiation that differs significantly from maturation occurring upon activation of other PKC subfamilies induced by phorbol ester treatment .

text: Increased expression of the <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protooncogene and an increase in AP-1 binding activity in <extra_id_0> PKC-zeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cells provides a potential mechanism for explaining the altered differentiation status of this cell .
